numbered_ace_sentences: 1. I can see from this chart that young people in most countries believe that the world is on a good path.
2. Young people in three countries are not more optimistic than elderly people.
3. Young people in other countries are more optimistic about the development of the world than elderly people.
4. UC Davis conducted a psychological survey.
5. According to the survey, the age 51 is the peak of optimism.
6. This chart does not seem to show that the age 51 is the peak of optimism.
7. This fact raises a question about the reliability of the data.
8. I ask whether this data is reliable enough.
9. I ask what the specific age is of a person who answered this question.
10. Assume that the data of this questionnaire is reliable.
11. Then a question arises.
12. An optimistic attitude towards the development of the world may not show that this person is an optimistic person.
13. In my opinion, the development of the world is an objective issue.
14. I am in China.
15. In China, epidemic protection is very strict.
16. In China, a person must present a QR code to enter a shopping mall.
17. In China, a person must present a QR code to enter some public areas.
18. A QR code proves that a person is healthy.
19. Many middle-aged people do not have a mobile phone.
20. Many elderly people do not have a mobile phone.
21. Many middle-aged people cannot use a mobile phone.
22. Many elderly people cannot use a mobile phone.
23. Many middle-aged people are rejected because they do not have a mobile phone or because they cannot use a mobile phone.
24. Many elderly people are rejected because they do not have a mobile phone or because they cannot use a mobile phone.
25. This rejection makes these people feel abandoned.
26. These people feel abandoned by the world.
27. This is a small example.
28. We can re-examine this chart.
